com.cloudera.oryx.als.computation

Class ALSDistributedGenerationRunner

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.cloudera.oryx.computation.common.GenerationRunner
      • com.cloudera.oryx.computation.common.DistributedGenerationRunner
        • com.cloudera.oryx.als.computation.ALSDistributedGenerationRunner
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Callable<Object>

    public final class ALSDistributedGenerationRunner
extends DistributedGenerationRunner

    This class will run one generation of the Computation Layer. It is essentially a client of Hadoop and starts and monitors a series of MapReduce jobs that complete the Computation Layer's work.

    This is an overview of the sequence of MapReduce jobs that can run as part of the ALS pipeline. While it is one flow, there are several distinct concerns inside of it, some optional. The core flow is presented first, followed by notes about secondary or optional aspects of the flow. These are presented in order of execution although in many cases some jobs run in parallel with others.

    In all cases, generation N's data is found at HDFS path /[bucket]/[N]/ (where N is padded to 5 digits so that lexical order equals numeric order). Locations are relative to this unless otherwise specified.

    • "varlong" refers to the representation long
    • "varint" refers to int
    • "idvalue" refers to IDValue
    • "floatarray" refers to float[]
    • "floatmap" refers to FastByIDFloatMap
    • "idset" refers to FastIDSet

    Core Steps

    SplitTestStep

    New input is always found in generation N under inbound/, in (compressed) CSV text files. This step splits the data into test and train data (if model.test-set-fraction is nonzero). These go into test/ and train/, respectively, unmodified.

    MergeNewOldStep

    Merges all data from last generation (including the last generation's test data) with new input in the current generation. The last generation's data exists in generation N-1 under input/ and test/ (because the test data was not part of the input to the prior generation). It encodes user,item,value tuples as user-(item,value) key/value pairs, in particular as varlong mapped to idvalue objects.

    This step merges old and new values by adding them. Here is where 'decay' of old data takes place too.

    Output goes to generation N's input/, and this is what drives all further computation in the generation.

    ToUserVectorsStep / ToItemVectorsStep

    These simply transform the output above into a mapping from user to all item/value pairs as a single floatmap object -- user vectors if you like -- and likewise for item vectors. The output goes to userVectors/ and itemVectors/ respectively.

    CollectKnownItemsStep

    Outputs user IDs mapped to a set of item IDs that the user ID has interacted with in the data set. The output is in text format, in knownItems/ and is for consumption by the Serving Layer.

    InitialYStep

    This process outputs an initial Y matrix. It will optionally reuse the final {code Y/} output from last generation, N-1. For any items that have no vector yet (which might be all of them on a fresh run) it will choose random unit vectors (chosen with kmeans++-style preference for dissimilar vectors). Output goes to tmp/iterations/0/Y, and is encoded as varlong mapped to floatarray.

    PopularUserStep / PopularItemStep

    Slightly misnamed, as they actually output the set of items that a given user interacts with in the data, and vice versa for items. The output is encoded as varlong mapped to idset, and the output goes to popularUsersByItemPartition and popularItemsByUserPartition respectively.. This is used later to cleverly side-load only the part of the X or Y matrix that will actually be used by a reducer.

    RowStep

    The heart of the ALS iteration, and the most important step in the flow. This is the one that is iterated many times. It will alternately compute X from Y, then Y from X. In the first case, for iteration i, input is from tmp/iterations/[i-1]/Y and output goes to tmp/iterations/[i]/X. In the second case, it's tmp/iterations/[i]/X going to {code tmp/iterations/[i]/Y}. Input and output are rows of a matrix: varlong mapped to floatarray.

    The core ALS computation here is fairly straightforward, but, there is complexity around side-loading the X or Y matrix, rather than literally joining the matrix on the input, which would be far too slow. To conserve memory, only keys that are expected to appear in the input to the particular reducer will be loaded.

    PublishXStep / PublishYStep

    Simple map-only jobs that publish the X or Y matrix, respectively, from the final iteration, in a form that's consumable by the Serving Layer. The output is compressed text format. See the source code for exact format. It is otherwise the same matrix as computed by the iterations. The output goes to X/ and Y/ respectively.

    Recommend Steps

    DistributeRecommendWorkStep

    This first step effectively joins data from X/ (user-feature matrix) and knownItems/, since both are needed to recommend for a user. It writes the combined values as varlong mapped to IDAndKnownItemsAndFloatArrayWritable. The output goes to tmp/distributeRecommend/. This is necessary as its own step because the shuffle/combiner will need to be used differently in the next step.

    RecommendStep

    This computes recommendations given output above. The item-features matrix, Y, is also needed. It is side-loaded cleverly as in RowStep. Each reducer makes N recommendations per user when N recommendations are desired. They will be condensed into N overall in the next step. The output goes to tmp/partialRecommend and is encoded as varlong (user ID) mapped to a series of idvalue objects representing top recommended items.

    CollectRecommendStep

    This stage simply takes output above and outputs final N recommendations for each user. Output is conceptually similar, but in text format, and goes to recommend/.

    Similarity Steps

    DistributeSimilarWorkStep

    Quite analogous to DistributeRecommendWorkStep and RecommendStep combined. Because there is no join needed, these two tasks can be accomplished in a single job.

    SimilarStep

    Quite analogous to CollectRecommendStep.

    Author:
    Sean Owen
